content.webTitle: Wales and Lions prop Adam Jones has retired from international rugby

fields.headline: Wales and Lions prop Adam Jones has retired from international rugby
fields.bodyText: Adam Jones, the prop who was central to Wales’ Six Nations defeat of England in 2013, has retired from international rugby after being left out of this year’s Six Nations squad. Jones, 33, who made 95 appearances for Wales, winning three Grand Slams, said that he made up his mind before Christmas that if he was not chosen for the Six Nations he would retire. “It’s obviously not the way I would want to finish, it’s not how I planned it, and I hope no one thinks I am simply quitting,” he told The Sunday Times. Jones acknowledged his Test career had been far from plain sailing of late, having missed out on the autumn international series and not playing for his country since June 2014. “It started when I got dropped for the last game of the 2014 Six Nations [against Scotland],” he said. “I was still pretty happy with the way everything was going, and I was thinking that I’d get back in. Then there was the ‘30-minute match’ in South Africa [when he was replaced by Samson Lee after half an hour].” Jones had been put on standby for the Six Nations and told by the coach Warren Gatland that the door remained open for a comeback, but the player said he had decided late last year that he would hang up his Test boots if overlooked. “I was gutted to miss out on the autumn,” the 2009 and 2013 British and Irish Lion added. “I told myself then that I would train as hard as I can and get as fit as I can. If it didn’t happen, then I’ll call it a day.” Jones does not agree with Gatland’s decision to overlook him, but thanked the Wales coach for being a “massive influence” on his career. “Warren is the man who came in and saved me,” Jones said. “He gave me a kick up the [backside] so he’s been a massive influence on me, and I’m very grateful. “I don’t agree with what he’s done now, I don’t agree with him not picking me. But he’s got to pick who he thinks is best.” Jones will continue playing for Cardiff Blues, who he joined on a one-year deal in August 2014.
